allQuestions.resource:
Tom is baking flapjacks for a bake sale. To produce 1 tray, Tom needs: 
250g porridge oats 
125g butter 
100g brown sugar 
100ml golden syrup 
The local supermarket prices are as follows:

questions.questionText: Tom plans to produce 4 trays. How much will the ingredients cost?

Tom accidentally burns 1 tray, so ends up having to spend £8.00 to make 4 trays and 1 burnt tray. Each non-burn tray is cut into 10 squares, and each square is sold for £1.80. Assuming all squares are sold, what percentage of profit did he gain from his earnings(Round up to nearest whole number).

The bake sale is almost over, and Tom still has lots of flapjacks left. He decides to discount the price of each square from £1.80 to £1.20. What is the ratio of the full price to the discounted price.
Tom aimed to sell all 40 flapjacks at £1.80. Next time, Tom wishes to earn £108.00 by selling 40 flapjacks, By what percentage does he need to increase the price of each square to achieve this?

allQuestions.resource:
John cycles from his house to Southampton in 3 hours, 30 minutes. He had three 10 minute rests. When he left, the reading on his odometer was 1276 miles. When he arrived, the reading on his odometer was 1315 miles. 
1 km = 0.6214 miles

questions.questionText: What was John’s average speed whilst cycling?
How many kilometres has John’s bike done when he arrives in Southampton?
John can do the same journey in 53 minutes by car. How much faster is John’s average driving speed compared to his average cycling speed?

When he bought the bike, it had 349 miles on the odometer. Mike borrowed John’s bike 6 times to cycle to and from work. Mike lives 3 miles from work. John has not lent the bike to anyone else. What is the total number of miles John has ridden on his bike since owning it when he arrives in Bournemouth?
